results.content: Whilst this is a good starter course, he does not properly call out the setting up of the security group. He creates one big security group as opposed to dividing it up. Also, he doesn't use an ALB with a target group and path/host based routing and instead uses NGINX.

response.content:
Hi,

I think there is some value in learning how nginx fits into the mix. Also the ALB has some limitations that the classic LB / nginx combo doesn't have such as HTTP to HTTPS redirects. That's not supported with ALB at this time which IMO makes it unusable for any real world set up without nginx.

As for the security groups, as you've seen, we run a lot of commands in this course and while we do cover a ton of extra info about AWS, I didn't want to focus on security groups as a deep dive (although there's really nothing insecure or broken about the set up we use in the course. It will work just fine for production).

It's clear Nick have a lot of knowledge, but need to focus/care more about time wasted, and learning experience...

1) WHYYYYY using aws CLI for this course instead of AWS Console ????
Seeing the teacher spelling letter by letter for VERY BIG commands in the terminal all the time , which probable the big majority of us will use these commands only a few times, really make me sad... it's a very time spent and totally non sense to drop down annotations, request docs, check if there is some typo for it, if we can simple go to console and simple DO (fast & easy)....

I watched the "docker for devops" course, and is the same history...

response.content:
Hi Ale,

I have a lecture dedicated to why I chose to use the CLI (at the start) instead of the AWS console (we use it later near the end). It's a couple of minutes long and highlights the perks.

You're talking about saving time, but with the CLI approach you can open up the PDF notes and just copy/paste the CLI commands if you want to fly through the course. That will certainly save you the most time, but you won't learn as much.

This course is very hands on. It is composed of both theory and workshop style follow-alongs where you're expected to follow along on your end so you can do the commands rather than just listen. You would definitely have trouble following along on a phone, that's for sure.

I'm a huge believer that learning is greatly accelerated and retained when you're actually doing things, instead of just passively watching. That's why my courses are loaded up with follow-alongs and coding challenges.

Perhaps you could read documentation on the subway to take advantage of your free time.

results.content:
I was expecting a course on running docker containers on AWS ECS. The course has some mechanical coverage of AWS CLI samples in this context. If you are looking for concepts or a bigger picture then better look someplace else.
after about 20 lectures ~20% of the course this tuns into "ruby on rails development on AWS" - nothing I am remotely interested in.

response.content:
Hi,

The course does go over running containers on AWS ECS and much more. The deep dive section goes over using the AWS CLI to work with the ECS resource specifically.

It's essential that you know how to interact and work with ECS. That's why there's a deep dive on it. It just so happens we do it through the CLI initially. This is where we start running Docker containers on the cluster you create very early on. We go over the web console later on in the course (and you'll know why once you get past the beginning lectures).

The Rails specific content is very small. We need some type of application to deploy, and you can easily apply this to whatever framework you want. I've already had students contact me and share their experiences using NodeJS and Django instead of Rails with great success.

There's nothing specific to Rails in this course other than it was the web framework used for a demo application. There's even a dedicated lecture showing you exactly how you could apply this to other frameworks.

If you look at the rest of the content in the course, it covers not only concepts but the bigger picture of applying everything together to solve the problem of deploying and scaling a real app with ECS. Load balancing, SSL, custom domains and everything else you could imagine is there. It's all in the curriculum of the course that's publicly available on the course's main page.

I recommend finishing the rest of the course because it sounds like you're assuming the course is about Rails because we talk about it for a few lectures when that's not the case at all.

Course is outdated!! It's not good that 3 years after it's originally authored, it is STILL using ClassicLoadBalancer to illustrate how load balancing works with ECS. 

ClassicLoadBalancer is a legacy tech and should be replaced either via ALB or NLB.

Not happy and want my money back

response.content:
Hi,

Everything still works completely fine today and I've added update videos for their new UI. It's still using the ClassicLoadBalancer because it took Amazon forever to eventually add support for the ALB to redirect http to https. There is also no benefit of using ALB vs the classic ELB in this case and NLB wouldn't make sense for this type of app.

results.content:
Nick did a great job covering the essentials of using Docker on AWS in a scalable way with this course. I now feel much more comfortable with the possibility of going directly to AWS for my applications as opposed to using something simpler (albeit more constrained and more expensive) like Heroku.

There were a few places where I had minor issues due to changes AWS and/or Docker have made since the course was released, but I was able to sort them out using existing posts in the course's Q&A boards, as well as the techniques covered in the course. Nick was very responsive after asking how I was doing in the course - we had a brief conversation about my discovery and solving of these issues, and he was so fast, it was almost like IM! It's really good to know he cares about his courses and his students and gives that much attention to supporting them.

The course also uses the "new" Docker Compose syntax which is fully up to date.

File download 404s tend to be issues with Udemy, not me, there's 1,000+ students who have gotten past step 2 without a 404, so I'm guessing there's a temporary problem with Udemy that's out of my control but without further details I cannot investigate it.

results.content:
Its great that course is focused on CLI. Still, it would be nice to give a hint where corresponding UI is located in AWS Console UI. 

I knew that this course is not matching for me 100% because i use .net core for backend. But it was not too hard to replace Ruby with .net core. 

Maybe its worth splitting RoR app into frontend as SPA on S3/CloudFront
and backend that provides REST api only - looks like more modern approach these days and will help understand AWS even more.

Also, too much specifics on nginx for course targeted more on docker in AWS. 
I just used "jwilder/nginx-proxy" docker image for reverse proxy - this allows to not get into all these nginx configs (much simpler).

What would be nice to see in this course:
- I believe its possible to use EC2 autoscaling groups for ECS - thats interesting.
- Advanced moniroting/logging

This course let me experiment a lot - and thats main benefit.
Thank you.

We're in the middle of switching to all the real things this course is about at my job. So it was perfect for what I needed.

I went from having to derail conversations to ask for reminders about the difference between (for example) a task and a service to being able to participate intelligently and help lead us through some of the design mine fields.

I was tempted to mark it down to 4.5 stars for that. But, honestly, a few rough edges aren't that bad. And debugging the problems would have been great homework assignments if I had more time.

I was tempted to mark it down to 4.5 stars for that. But, honestly, a few rough edges aren't that bad. And debugging the problems would have been great homework assignments if I had more time.

results.content:
I have 40+ courses bought on Udemy, but this is first when I leave anything less than four stars.

Nick treats students like idiots. He spells (slooowly) every letter in every command. Literally. Like 'docker dash dash [ti][ai] capital [ar]' and so on. For minutes. Every lecture he spends minutes to explain (for the twentieth time!) how to unzip(!) a file from course materials. A lot of time wasted that way. 

Most of this course has nothing to do with Docker or scaling. The whole section is dedicated to building an actual RoR app. Not just launching, actually developing with models, migrations, actions and all. 

A lot of stuff is about AWS, not AWS ECS. Nick shows how to create EC2 instances, S3 buckets, security groups, copy files etc. This might be helpful for some students, but I think this stuff is for another course.

There are a lot of repetitions. Section 8 just repeats, again, what we've seen in earlier sections.

response.content:
Hi,

Sorry you didn't like every aspect of the course, but I don't think it's fair to say I treat students like idiots. I definitely don't do that.

Also, this course includes much more than ECS because in order to scale a web application on AWS it also requires using things like S3, security groups, EC2 instances, ELB, etc.. There's no way around that. In this course we tie all of those together (including ECS in detail) to perform the end goal of scaling a Dockerized app on AWS.

Lots of students have successfully applied this course to Flask, Node and other web frameworks. I happened to use Rails as a working example because it's a well defined framework that has common things (such as background workers and migrations) which are present in most frameworks.

The reason I included developing the Rails app (which I mention you can skip on video if you're not interested) is because it demonstrates how to Dockerize a web app.

Also, not every lecture has zip files, only a few do and I just spot checked them. On average I spend 8 seconds explaining how to do it, and the only reason I do this on video is because it's important that those files get extracted to the correct folder.

I went for that approach because in previous courses one of the top problems students had were they extracted files to the wrong directory (written examples weren't enough) so I showed it on camera this time around and I haven't seen a single person get mixed up when extracting files which I would consider a success!

There's no way around that. In this course we tie all of those together (including ECS in detail) to perform the end goal of scaling a Dockerized app on AWS.

Lots of students have successfully applied this course to Flask, Node and other web frameworks. I happened to use Rails as a working example because it's a well defined framework that has common things (such as background workers and migrations) which are present in most frameworks.

Also, not every lecture has zip files, only a few do and I just spot checked them. On average I spend 8 seconds explaining how to do it, and the only reason I do this on video is because it's important that those files get extracted to the correct folder.

I went for that approach because in previous courses one of the top problems students had were they extracted files to the wrong directory (written examples weren't enough) so I showed it on camera this time around and I haven't seen a single person get mixed up when extracting files which I would consider a success!
